conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Honestly, I’m terrified of networking events—I freeze up and can’t even introduce myself without overthinking. I know I need to get better at this if I want grad school or a career, but it feels impossible right now."

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10
- Agreeableness: 1/10
- Conscientiousness: 6/10
- Neuroticism: 8/10
- Openness: 7/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start small by practicing introductions with just one person at each event. Have a simple script ready like "Hi, I'm Gregory - what brings you here today?" to take the pressure off.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, scripts feel so fake though... but I guess it's better than standing there like an idiot. Maybe I'll try it at the CS department mixer next week - if I can actually make myself go.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Focus on the other person by asking questions - this shifts attention away from your nerves. At the mixer, aim to learn one interesting thing about each person you meet.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds way less terrifying than trying to sell myself. I can handle asking questions - I do that in study groups all the time. Maybe I'll just pretend it's a really big study group... with better snacks.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you've found an approach that works for you. Remember, most people at mixers feel just as nervous - you're not alone in this. Good luck at the event!

I ask questions to show interest in others.

I accept invitations to social events.
I manage my stress in social situations.
I build rapport with people quickly.

improvement_areas: I listen attentively without interrupting.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I’m really struggling with networking and interviews—just thinking about them makes me freeze up, but I know I need to get better if I want to find a job after graduation. Do you have any advice for someone who… well, hates small talk and overanalyzes every interaction?

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10
- Agreeableness: 9/10
- Conscientiousness: 8/10
- Neuroticism: 4/10
- Openness: 1/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start by practicing small talk in low-stakes situations, like chatting with cashiers or classmates. Focus on simple open-ended questions ("How's your day going?") rather than worrying about perfect responses. Would you be open to trying that this week?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That sounds... terrifying, but I guess I could try with the barista at the campus coffee shop. I always go there anyway. Do you think it's weird if I practice with the same person multiple times? I don't want them to think I'm strange.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Not at all - regulars who chat briefly with staff are completely normal! Start with just a smile and "How's your shift going?" - most service workers appreciate friendly customers. Would you feel more comfortable writing down 2-3 simple questions to have ready?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah... maybe I could write "How's your day?" and "Busy today?" on my coffee sleeve as reminders. I just worry I'll blank in the moment and stare awkwardly. Do people usually respond to those kinds of questions? I don't want to bother them.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: They absolutely respond - those are standard friendly exchanges! Most people will give a quick answer (like "Good, thanks!" or "Yeah, super busy"), which gives you an easy way to practice without pressure. Sounds like you've got a solid starter plan with the coffee sleeve reminders - give it a try!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay... I'll try it tomorrow morning. If I mess up, at least I never have to go back to that coffee shop again, right? Just kidding. Mostly. Thanks for helping me break this down into smaller steps - it feels less overwhelming now.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you've got a good attitude about it! Remember, even if it feels awkward at first, the barista won't overthink it - they're used to quick chats. You've got this!

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I’m really worried about finding a job after graduation—I love art history, but what if there aren’t any opportunities? And honestly, I don’t even know where to start looking.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10
- Agreeableness: 10/10
- Conscientiousness: 4/10
- Neuroticism: 8/10
- Openness: 3/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 2/10
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Campus social events
- Social comfort: 3/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Art History
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Homesickness
- Goals: Land a dream internship, Start a student organization, Graduate with honors, Improve time management
- Challenges: Balancing extracurricular activities with studies, Building time management, Financial planning, Developing effective study habits
- Behaviors: Uses campus resources like tutoring, Seeks out leadership roles, Studies in the library regularly

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start by researching art history-related roles (museums, galleries, archives) and adjacent fields like arts education or nonprofit work. Would it help to brainstorm some specific job titles to explore?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds practical—I could make a list tonight. But how do I know which jobs would actually be realistic for someone just out of college? The museum curator positions I see online all want 5+ years experience.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Look for entry-level roles like gallery assistant, museum educator, or collections technician—these often require less experience. Would you like help identifying transferable skills from your coursework that could strengthen your applications?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, that makes sense—I've done some cataloging projects in class that could apply to collections work. But I still feel underqualified when I read job descriptions. Maybe I should talk to my professors about internship opportunities first?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great idea—professors often have industry connections and can recommend internships or entry-level roles. Would you like help drafting an email to reach out to them?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That would be perfect—I always get nervous emailing professors outside of class. Could you help me keep it professional but not too formal? Maybe mention my cataloging project in Dr. Chen's class since she knows that work.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
"Dear Dr. [Last Name],  
I really enjoyed working on the [specific project] in your class and was wondering if you know of any internships or entry-level roles in collections work. I'd appreciate any advice or connections you might suggest.  

Best,  
Alex"  

Want to tweak this together?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That sounds good, but could we make it a little warmer? Maybe add something like "I've been thinking about how much I enjoyed the hands-on cataloging work" before asking about opportunities? I don't want to seem too transactional.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
"Dear Dr. [Last Name],  
I’ve been reflecting on how much I enjoyed the hands-on cataloging work in your [specific project]—it really solidified my interest in collections. I’m exploring internship or entry-level roles in this area and would value any advice or connections you might suggest.  

Best,  
Alex"  

Want to adjust anything else?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's perfect—it feels genuine but still professional. Thanks for helping me find the right tone. I'll send this to Dr. Chen tomorrow before my nerves get the better of me.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you've got a solid plan. Good luck with Dr. Chen—you've struck a great balance between warmth and professionalism!

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I’m really struggling with presentations—they make me freeze up, and I’m worried it’ll hold me back in my career. Do you have any advice for managing the anxiety while still being professional?

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 5/10
- Agreeableness: 7/10
- Conscientiousness: 5/10
- Neuroticism: 5/10
- Openness: 5/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 10/10
- Communication style: Indirect
- Triggers: Presentations
- Social comfort: 5/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Journalism
- Fears: Academic failure and poor grades, Balancing social life and studies, Finding a job after graduation
- Goals: Learn coding and programming, Learn a new language, Learn about different cultures, Publish a paper
- Challenges: Navigating campus politics, Developing effective study habits, Dealing with homesickness
- Behaviors: Seeks out leadership roles, Goes to campus events, Attends career fairs, Exercises regularly, Uses social media for networking

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Practice deep breathing before you start—inhale for 4 seconds, hold for 4, exhale for 6. Also, focus on just 2-3 key points instead of memorizing everything—this makes it feel less overwhelming. Would you like to try a quick practice run together?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That breathing technique sounds helpful—I'll try it before my next presentation. And focusing on just a few points makes sense, since I always over-prepare and then panic about remembering everything. Maybe we could practice with a short intro to my next assignment?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: just state your topic, why it matters, and the 2-3 main points you'll cover. Ready to give it a try now?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, let's try... My topic is about ethical dilemmas in photojournalism. It matters because images shape public opinion but can also exploit subjects. My main points will be about consent, context, and the photographer's responsibility. *takes deep breath* How was that?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That was great—clear, concise, and structured! Notice how focusing on just those core elements made it feel more manageable? Keep that same approach for your full presentation. Sounds like you've got a solid plan. Good luck!

I ask for help when I need it.

I join group activities.

I notice when others are uncomfortable.

I share personal experiences appropriately.
I give compliments sincerely.

I maintain friendships.
I respect personal boundaries.
I speak at an appropriate volume.
I stay calm when dealing with problems.
I read social cues accurately.
I contribute to group discussions.
I show interest in others' lives.

improvement_areas: I start conversations with new people.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Honestly, I’m terrified of networking events—I freeze up every time I have to talk to professionals. How do I even start building connections when just thinking about it makes me want to hide in the library?"

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10
- Agreeableness: 4/10
- Conscientiousness: 1/10
- Neuroticism: 4/10
- Openness: 3/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 7/10
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Networking events, Campus social events, Meeting new people, Job interviews
- Social comfort: 1/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Engineering
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Networking with professionals
- Goals: Get a research position, Publish a paper
- Challenges: Navigating campus politics, Overcoming procrastination, Financial planning, Career exploration
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Uses social media for networking, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start small - prepare 2-3 simple questions beforehand like "What brought you to this event?" or "What projects are you working on?" This gives you a script to fall back on when nervous.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, scripts make me feel even more awkward—like I'm reading lines in a bad play. But I guess having a couple questions ready beats standing there like a deer in headlights. What if they ask me something I don't know how to answer though?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: When you don't know an answer, it's okay to say "That's a great question - I'm still learning about that myself." Most professionals appreciate honesty more than a fake answer.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually takes some pressure off—I always feel like I need to have all the answers. But what if they think I'm dumb for not knowing? Engineering folks can be brutal about that stuff.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Most professionals remember being students too - they'll respect you more for being genuine than pretending. Focus on showing curiosity rather than expertise.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Man, I wish I had your confidence. I've seen some engineers rip apart undergrads for not knowing basic concepts during networking events. Maybe I just need to find the right people to talk to—less intimidating ones.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try targeting younger professionals or recent grads first—they're usually more approachable and remember the student experience well. Look for name tags with junior titles or alumni from your school.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's actually a solid strategy—I always go straight for the senior people thinking they'll be most impressed if I talk to them. But yeah, the junior engineers probably won't make me feel like an idiot for not knowing some obscure technical detail.
